title: Tuesday, 31st October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:01am

Plenty of news around this morning

PM11:01am

Well, lots of statements

11:01 am
PM11:01am

But what to start with...

PM11:02am

Bond Vigilantes have a bunch of scary charts for Halloween

PM11:02am

One of those will do

11:02 am
PM11:02am

PM11:02am

https://www.bondvi...lebrate-halloween/

PM11:03am

It is kinda extraordinary how total debt just gets bigger and bigger and bigger

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Central bank buying keeping rates low

PM11:03am

How do you reverse that? Just don't know

PM11:04am

Anyway, best crack on

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Footsie flat, but a number of issues rather less so

PM11:04am

Where to start Bryce? Burberry? Bookies?

PM11:05am

Or straight into some of the figures?

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Anywhere you like, really. Burberry would be good to get out of the way early, I guess.

PM11:05am

Yeah, and it's fresh

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,900, down 22 (-1.14%), High: 1,927, Low: 1,857, Volume: 1.67m
11:05 am
PM11:05am

Mr Bailey is bailing

PM11:06am

Luvvie statement here https://www.invest...1710310939250834V/

BE11:06am

Stepping down as of March 2018.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Though he'll hang around to "provide support" until December 2018.

PM11:06am

The joint boss thing was never going to last

PM11:06am

Yeah, saw that

11:06 am
PM11:07am

But then he's had to surrender all his incentive stock

PM11:07am

And there's quite a bit of it

PM11:07am

£16m of it, in fact

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Details here https://www.invest...1710311020370954V/

BE11:07am

The long transition period stuff all looks rather too cosy, really, though from outside the boardroom we can never be entirely sure who's shouting at whom.

BE11:08am

I mean, it has been speculated that Mr Bailey's departure was under pressure from some activist types.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

As in, his departure from the CEO job.

BE11:09am

And the most common criticism of Burberry in recent times was that it has become a stale brand. Needed to do a Gucci, get fresh blood in.

PM11:09am

Indeed

11:09 am
BE11:10am

The pitch that Bailey's push to focus solely on being A Creative looked a lot like ego protection rather than an actual strategic plan.

BE11:10am

Here's UBS

BE11:10am

We expect Christopher Bailey to be in charge of the February fashion show for Autumn/ Winter 2018 but could expect a new Creative Director in place to design the Spring/ Summer 2019 collection which shows in September 2018. We note Christopher Bailey will receive his final bonus awards in July 2018 but is not entitled to a bonus for the April-December 2018 period. He is forfeiting additional share awards of c.£16m granted between 2014 and 2017 (at yesterday's close).

11:10 am
BE11:10am

We rate Burberry Buy given the opportunity to structurally improve sales densities, drive cost efficiencies, and run a more efficient capital structure. The recent arrival of CFO Julie Brown has delivered some early progress, but new CEO Marco Gobbetti's market address should spark the next stage for investors particularly with respect to how he plans to improve like-for-like trends for the brand.

BE11:11am

Note this is quite soon ahead of the H1.

BE11:11am

Due November 9.

11:11 am
PM11:12am

Do you think there's actually been a bust up here?

BE11:12am

So this could be seen more as a bit of housekeeping ahead of Gobbetti announcing his grand plan.

BE11:12am

Doubt it's a bust up, but what do I know? Not much, in short. Here's JPM on what to expect.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

The 9th of Nov presentation will also mark the first time CEO Mr Gobbetti will present to the investment community and update us on a strategic plan that was crafted before he joined. There are rising expectations that Mr Gobbetti will announce further restructuring of US wholesale. We indeed see this as a likely outcome. Burberry itself states that 'markets are at a different stage of maturity' in terms of distribution channels with the US 30% wholesale vs Asia Pac 10%. A change in leadership at Burberry Americas should also make reset decisions easier. We calculate that cutting wholesale in the US to 15% of US Sales would represent an underlying loss of revenue of c£103m and EBIT of £17m. We would also expect Mr Gobbetti to expand on the leather goods ambitions (recall Mr Gobbetti comes from Celine and has heavily recruited from LG (head of merchandising and LG design from Dior).

BE11:13am

And Kepler .....

BE11:13am

While we welcome this change, we maintain our wait-and-see position for the time being. We have no doubt that the brand will become more attractive. The question is when. We expect brand momentum to remain unsettled for several months and see only limited room for improvement, since it will take some time for the improvements the company has made to pay off. In the longer term, we expect sales and margins to increase, as the plan will gradually deliver its full potential both on cost savings and new collections being implemented. We will closely monitor trading, chasing the first sign of improving sales momentum.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

In light with what is happening at Ferragamo with another general EPS downgrade assuming a further delay in the expected recovery in sales and profitability due to the late implementation of key marketing actions (thus shifting the timing of a turnaround by at least two quarters), we believe it is possible that the same will happen to Burberry. That could be the start of a phase in which things get worse before they get better. We are particularly concerned by the situation with department stores in the US.

BE11:15am

So, an argument can be made that the shares are down not because of Bailey's departure -- which doesn't matter much other for continuity -- but because it might be clearing the decks for a reset next month.

BE11:15am

Maybe.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

hmm. seems fair

undefined
PM11:16am

ROTR have raised WPP

11:16 am
PM11:17am

No respite there

PM11:17am

Q3s here https://www.invest...1710310700040637V/

PM11:17am

But the stock is stable enough

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Stable at a 52 week low, tho.

WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,308, up 13 (+1.00%), High: 1,312, Low: 1,260, Volume: 3.09m
PM11:18am

Sell off already happend

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The stock would be rather higher if we added Sorrell's annual salary back onto the market cap, I note in passing, though that's not an entirely fair observation.

BE11:19am

So, numbers okay but a soft warning in there as well.

BE11:19am

Q3 organic growth of -1.1% looks bad but was better than a -1.3% consensus.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Guidance is for broadly flat FY organic growth, against the +10bps previously expected.

BE11:21am

As you say, though, none of this is a surprise. Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:21am

We are already looking for -0.4% for organic net sales growth for 2017, which looks about right given the new guidance. We looked for a c15bps margin improvement, and WPP is now saying flat at constant currency. At the nine month stage reported margins were up c10bps, ahead of constant currency margins up slightly. With yoy sterling less favourable in Q4 we think the
reported and constant currency margins will be similar for the year. WPP is getting a boost to its margins in 2017 from the strong performance of associates, which will not recur in 2018.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Consensus could come down 1-2% in 2017: Feeding this through to consensus we think that market consensus forecasts may reduce in the order of c£30m, which is c1-2% off consensus 2017 pretax and would bring eps down a similar amount to c119-120p.

BE11:22am

One interesting detail in here is that net debt was up £1bn in the quarter

BE11:22am

To £5.7bn

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Cyber attackery gets the blame, as well as implementation of some Indian tax thing.

BE11:23am

So, Q4 should be a bit better.

PM11:24am

Sorrell's discussion about why 2017 has proved to be a "different kettle of fish" was interesting

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Given that he ends up blaming activist investors

PM11:25am

Goes through the Google/Facebook effect. The digital consultants

PM11:25am

And then...

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Thirdly, and finally, there is a view that post-Lehman central bank easy or loose monetary policy has resulted in consistently low interest rates which, in turn, has caused some distortion in capital allocation. Clients in any event have had to deal with the impact of digital disruption from say Airbnb in the hospitality industry, or Uber in transportation or Amazon or Alibaba in distribution. But, in addition, they have now been forced to focus even more on cost reduction in response to activist investors (for example, Nelson Peltz at Procter & Gamble or Dan Loeb at Nestlé, who claim to be proponents of increased marketing spend), or the consolidation threat of zero-based budgeters such as 3G or Reckitt Benckiser or Coty, or previously Valeant or Endo in the pharmaceutical industry. Kraft Heinz's transitory bid for Unilever, was a seminal moment as it suggested no one was safe, irrespective of size.

PM11:25am

There is little or no doubt that this third factor has had a significant, almost Pavlovian impact on variable cost reduction and encouraging a short-term focus, particularly in the fast moving consumer goods sector, which accounts for about 30% of our revenue, but it has also had a further impact on other sectors, such as autos and pharmaceuticals. Neither has this been helped by the fact that the average S&P 500 or FTSE 100 CEO has a life expectancy of 6-7 years, the average CFO 4-5 years and the average CMO 2-3 years. As a result, the S&P 500 is now consistently paying back around 100% of its earnings to share owners in the form of dividends and buybacks, as opposed to about 60% in 2009, post-Lehman. Effectively management is abrogating responsibility for reinvesting retained earnings back to share owners.

PM11:26am

So actually, by extension, he's baming QE

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Which is what I do -- blame everything on QE

BE11:27am

Hm ............ I'd be interested to see if there's any correlation between FMCG ad spend and FMCG unit sales.

BE11:27am

ROTR, over to you.

11:27 am
undefined
BE11:27am

Hey, since we're on FMCG (sort of) ....

BE11:27am

A few interesting-ish things in the US overnight.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Firstly, Dunkin' Brands Group

BE11:28am

Streetinsider, I think, did one of their single-source things about JAB looking again.

BE11:28am

Which seems plausible, though not obvious.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

For reasons set out by Baird .....

BE11:29am

For our perspective, JAB has made a large number of acquisitions in the coffee/breakfast category over the past 5+ years, with a current portfolio that includes Keurig Green Mountain (acquired in 2016), Krispy Kreme (2016), Einstein Noah (2014), D.E, Master Blenders (2013), Caribou Coffee (2013), Peet's Coffee & Tea (2012), and several other smaller coffee brands. JAB also acquired Panera Bread earlier this year. While we would hesitate to assume a high probability of a JAB acquisition of Dunkin', we would not rule out the possibility, given our view that Dunkin' appears to represent a strong fit within JAB's investment philosophy.

BE11:30am

Of note, JAB has been willing to pay substantial valuation premiums in past acquisitions, including close to 18X trailing EBITDA for both Panera and Krispy Kreme. A hypothetical buyout of DNKN at 18X trailing EBITDA would imply an equity value near $72/share (24% above current price).

11:31 am
BE11:31am

And also by William Blair, which I'll screenshot rather than transcribe.

BE11:31am

BE11:32am

Now, I note the Dunkin stuff in part because of a similar sudden burst of interest around JM Smucker.

11:32 am
PM11:32am

ok...

BE11:32am

Maker of Crisco oil, Jif peanut butter, Folger’s coffee, and a lot of pet food.

PM11:01am

Welcome to ML

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Anyway, Smucker trades at a big discount to the sector -- at about 12x 2018, 25% less than peers

BE11:33am

Which is in part because it's not seen to be a consolidation target. Dual class shares are a poison pill to protect family ownership

BE11:33am

The family only have about 4% I think, but it's a dynasty. Mark Smucker succeeded Richard Smucker as CEO in 2016. Richard Smucker moved up to executive chairman and Timothy Smucker is chairman emeritus.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

The connection to the above is that Smucker's great white hope right now is Dunkin' Donuts Keurig® K-Cup® Pods.

BE11:34am

Which are like Nespresso, but ..... uh, for cops? Not sure.

BE11:34am

So anyway, why the interest? Dunno. I note that Smucker's three-year plan hasn't been doing much for its share price ....

11:34 am
PM11:35am

What the hell is a Dunkin' Donuts Keurig® K-Cup® Pod??

BE11:35am

Dunkin Donuts is a premium coffee brand for a lot of America, it seems.

PM11:36am

11:35 am
BE11:36am

And the ability to drink Dunkin Donuts coffee at home from your K-Pod machine is an attractive prospect commercially.

BE11:36am

Yes, that. Those. Them.

BE11:36am

So anyway, we don't know what's happening here. It's not implausible that an activist or something could move in, or even that Smucker could act without prompting and go for a spinoff or something.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

That is entirely my speculation though. To be clear.

BE11:37am

I note it only as one to keep an eye on.

undefined
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Qualcomm mentioned on the right.

BE11:38am

Another one people have been .... uh ..... keeping an eye on over the past week or so.

PM11:38am

That's down 5% pre-mareket, I note

11:38 am
PM11:38am

market

BE11:38am

All sorts of noise around Qualcomm in recent days, ahead of the WSJ story that Apple's looking at designing it out of iThings.

BE11:39am

https://www.wsj.co...ponents-1509408668

11:39 am
BE11:39am

..... which is a good story, but also a fairly predictable one.

BE11:39am

Apple and Qualcomm have been in dispute, and we've seen Apple's strategy on dual sourcing.

BE11:40am

As in, "play along or we'll go in-house and crush you".

11:40 am
BE11:40am

See Imagination for a recent example, or Wolfson for one rather further back.

BE11:41am

So, the idea of Qualcomm getting cut out of Apple product looks a lot like a bit of gamesmanship ahead of Qualcomm's pending Q3s.

BE11:42am

Morgan Stanley:

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Current QTL customers may feel emboldened to not fully comply with license agreements in an attempt to leverage the Apple lawsuit (which we do not expect any updates on Wednesday) and the ongoing dispute with the unnamed licensee. We have remained EW on QCOM in contemplating this risk, which we believe pressures Qualcomm to meaningfully increase investments into smartphone ecosystems to ensure compliance with non-iPhone OEMs and eventually entice a settlement with Apple.

undefined
PM11:43am

This FOBT review mentioned on the right

11:43 am
PM11:43am

I only read the exec summary

PM11:43am

But it didn't seem to take us much further forward

BE11:44am

Yes! It's ............ odd. I think we had a pop at the Times yesterday about doing a story despite not having the proposed stake cut figure.

11:43 am
PM11:44am

All we know was that the cap will be between 2 and 50 quid

PM11:44am

Which we already knew

BE11:44am

Yes. We should apologise to the Times, because the government doesn't have a stake figure either.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

There's basically nothing in here. It's baffling.

PM11:45am

62 pages of baffle

PM11:45am

https://www.gov.uk...ility_Measures.pdf

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We're going to £50, £30, £20, £2, after a 12 week review.

BE11:46am

Complete fudge, kicking the can, fiddling while Rome etc's ..... pick your cliche and it's probably accurate.

BE11:46am

And it means all the sellside can just repurpose their old research, yet again.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Here's Canaccord.

BE11:47am

This decision comes as no surprise. The only
Certainty was that the current level of £100 was going to be cut. There is no review of densities of machines in betting shops, which
is a positive for the industry, and while it refers to a potential review of spin speeds, this is certainly not an area that has been highlighted. Government has also rejected calls for a relaxation of regulations on other machines - so no rise in machine densities for casinos, which removes a potential positive for Rank (RNK-LSE : 232p | Buy, TP 265p).
Overall, surprisingly few decisions have been made after a year of deliberation. But the new review does point to a consensual outcome, which reduces the risks to the Retail Betting companies.

BE11:47am

We still think that a £20 maximum stake is significantly the most likely outcome. And it is one which we believe would be greeted favourably by investors, given the weak share price performances of Ladbrokes (LCL-LSE : 125p | Buy, TP 165p) and William Hill (WMH-LSE : 253p | Hold, TP 285p) over the past year, down 7% and 15% respectively.
We estimate that a £20 maximum stake would drive a 22% hit to Ladbrokes 2020 Ebitda before mitigation from shop closures (or -19%, post closure of 400 shops) and a 32% hit to EPS (-26%, post shop closures). For William Hill, the impact would be -19%/-24% after mitigation from shop closures. By comparison, a £2 max stake would knock an initial 60% off LCL EPS in 2020, or 58% off WMH, with the Retail businesses loss making before shop closures. Post mitigation (and we see LCL closing 1000 stores in this scenario), we see EPS for the two companies coming down by c.45%.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And Barclays.

BE11:48am

There are a few statements which could be viewed as suggesting a cut to £2 is not the most likely outcome. There is some balanced commentary with regards to i) appreciating the issue of problem gambling is bigger than just reducing maximums stakes on B2 machines to £2, ii) the DCMS makes reference to the need for the sector to contribute towards the wider economy (50k people employed by UK retail, all gambling taxes contributed towards c. 0.5% of government taxes). So what is new? The DCMS confirms that maximum stakes on B2 machines will be cut from £100 to between £2 to £50 (specific levels are £50, £30, £20, £2): this is not a surprise and the market is pricing in a cut, in our view. The government confirms that the consultation period will end on 23/1/18: this is new news and the date will go into investors outlook calendars this morning. The DCMS states that it is ‘aware that the factors which influence the extent of harm to the player are wider than one product, or a limited set of parameters such as stakes and prizes, and include factors around the player, the environment and the product.’ We view this statement as relatively balanced and suggests the DCMS appreciates that simply reducing the max stakes to £2 will not stop the wider issue of problem gambling. An additional statement which could be viewed as constructive is that the DCMS seeks to ensure that ‘we have the right balance between a sector that can grow and contribute to the economy, and one that is socially responsible…’: again we think this suggests that the materially negative impact a cut to £2 would have to government tax take is being balanced between the need to reduce max stakes.

Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 127.90, up 2.6 (+2.08%), High: 128.80, Low: 125.50, Volume: 8.58m
11:49 am
Paddy Power Betfair PLC (PPB:LSE): Last: 7,580, down 25 (-0.33%), High: 7,610, Low: 7,520, Volume: 18.27k
William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 261.10, up 8.6 (+3.41%), High: 261.60, Low: 252.70, Volume: 2.20m
PM11:51am

Meanwhile, with a different type of gambling...

11:51 am
Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 1,043, up 46 (+4.62%), High: 1,050, Low: 1,017, Volume: 845.14k
PM11:51am

See their figures? Extraordinary

BE11:51am

Hm.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Dunno how they've done it

PM11:52am

Revenue up by 50%, new customers up by 70%

PM11:52am

Customer acquisition costs halving

11:52 am
PM11:52am

I was completely wrong on this one -- all the way up

BE11:53am

......................... as we (or I) have said often, whether its share price goes up or down isn't the only measure of a company.

PM11:53am

quick bit of Liberum

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Today's Q3'17 IMS is very strong and once again proves the resilience of the business in what has been a year characterized by increased regulation in Europe. The regulatory barriers could increase further in CY18 as ESMA is due to issue new guidelines in Q1'18. Consequently, we continue to err on the side of caution in relation to our own forecasts but given performance to date, we would not be surprised to see a continuation of the positive trend.

PM11:54am

Yes, this could be the crypto mania

BE11:54am

11:55 am
BE11:55am

As well as crypto, it's also a story of affiliate marketing .....

BE11:55am

http://www.500affiliates.com/

BE11:56am

.... and the consequences of a regulatory shakeout of sorts, which benefits those to have fallen foul of the checks first and sorted their processes.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

We use the term "regulatory arbitrage" a lot about Uber and so on. But we rarely use it about Plus500, GVC and so on. And it's just as applicable, if not more so.

PM11:57am

Yep

undefined
11:57 am
PM11:58am

What do we squeeze in before the hour's up?

BE11:58am

Haven't paid a lot of attention to requests, apologies.

BE11:58am

Think Just Sell was mentioned at the start though.

11:58 am
Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 765.00, up 25 (+3.38%), High: 792.00, Low: 748.00, Volume: 3.50m
PM11:59am

It was

BE11:59am

Another record high.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

And it's dangerously near going into the FTSE 100 at the next review, I think.

PM11:59am

Omg smile

BE12:00pm

Results are ahead, guidance (for revenues) increased.

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

(chad_john -- yup)

BE12:00pm

Though EBITDA guidance doesn't move, which apparently isn't a disappointment.

BE12:01pm

UK orders growing 22% yoy

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Let me grab the KPI chart from Citi, which helps emphasise how (if you're a believer) everything is moving in the right direction.

BE12:03pm

PM12:04pm

So Citi don't bother with a profits line either

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

That is just the KPIs, but sort of, yes. You don't buy Just Eat on current profitability.

undefined

Look at the time

12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

Sorry if we couldnt meet requests

PM12:06pm

But we'll be back tomorrow

PM12:06pm

11am sharp

12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

PM12:06pm

BE11:32am

Kibbles N’Bits, Milk-Bone, that kind of thing. Smucker products are in more than nine-tenths of US kitchens apparently.
